title: The Dictionary of Misunderstanding
main:
Have you ever discovered that a word you thought you knew actually means something different? These are mine, and a few others I've heard of.
All IPA pronunciations, audio pronunciations, and definitions in the "Actual" columns below are from the English Wiktionary, an online dictionary. They are licensed under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike 3.0 Unported License. This information was created cooperatively by thousands of editors (complete list). I have adapted the pronunciations to use more accurate transcriptions of glides. I also used Wiktionary to find quotes from other sources.
acrid
adjective (comparable)
Expected Actual
Pronunciation (IPA, Canada / US)
/ˈækɹɪd/
Meanings Acidic
Sharp and harsh, or bitter and not to the taste
Causing heat and irritation
Caustic; bitter; bitterly irritating
The cheapest way to clear logged woodland is to burn it, producing an acrid cloud of foul white smoke that, carried by the wind, can cover hundreds, or even thousands, of square miles.
—2013 June 29, "Unspontaneous combustion", in The Economist, volume 407, number 8842, page 29
becalm
verb (transitive)
Expected Actual
Pronunciation (IPA, Canada / US) /bijˈkɑ(l)m/ /bɪˈkɑm/
Meanings To lull into a false sense of security
To deprive (a ship) of wind, so that it cannot move
In the following two days, they made fast progress, strong easterly winds driving them down the Channel to where it opened out into the Atlantic; there, they were briefly becalmed.
—2011, Thomas Penn, Winter King, published 2012, page 214
benevolent
adjective (comparable)
Expected Actual
Pronunciation (IPA, Canada / US) /bɛnəˈvowlənt/ /bəˈnɛvələnt/
Pronunciation (audio, Canada / US)
Meanings Malevolent
Having a disposition to do good
Altruistic, charitable, good, just and fair
This bill was not a gift from a benevolent legislature; it was a victory for the community which worked for its passage.
—1989 December 24, Kevin M. Cathcart, "Homophobia Never Innocent", in Gay Community News, volume 17, number 24, page 5
blessed
adjective (comparable)
Expected Actual
Pronunciation (IPA, Canada / US)
/ˈblɛsɪd/
Meanings Pious
Having divine aid, or protection, or other blessing
Held in veneration; revered
Worthy of worship
Had I now had the sense to have gone back to Hull, and have gone home, I had been happy, and my father, as in our blessed Saviour’s parable, had even killed the fatted calf for me; for hearing the ship I went away in was cast away in Yarmouth Roads, it was a great while before he had any assurances that I was not drowned.
—1719, Daniel Defoe, Robinson Crusoe
boutique (as in "boutique law firm")
adjective (incomparable)
Expected Actual
Pronunciation (IPA, Canada / US)
/buwˈtijk/
Meanings A company which relies heavily on the value of its brand,rather than the quality of its product or service
Any company that has an exclusively smaller client base generally in a niche market or specializing in bespoke or custom-made products or services.
To keep attracting clients, the law firm of the future just might turn into a legal boutique, says Earle Yaffa, the managing director […]
—1982, ABA Journal, volume 68, page 661
catechize
verb (transitive)
Expected Actual
Pronunciation (IPA, Canada / US)
/ˈkætɪkajz/
Pronunciation (audio, Canada / US)
Meanings To include a work in, or add it to, the canon of Scripture
To give oral instruction, especially of religion; (specifically) by the formal question-and-answer method
To question at length
conclave
noun (countable)
Expected Actual
Pronunciation (IPA, Canada / US)
/ˈkɑnklejv/
Pronunciation (audio, Canada / US)
Meanings A recession in the side of a cliff, which can serve as a shelter
(Roman Catholicism) The set of apartments in which cardinals are secluded while the process to elect a pope takes place
A closed, private, or secret meeting, especially one of an ecclesiastical nature
Now you are all dispersed and scattered: no discussions, no committees, little correspondence—and you yourself are ever brooding and ever in conclave, with persons too who I know, for Stephen has told me so, are the preachers of violence […]
—1845, Benjamin Disraeli, chapter III, in Sybil or The Two Nations, volume III, book V, page 40
deft
adjective (comparable)
Expected Actual
Pronunciation (IPA, Canada / US)
/dɛft/
Pronunciation (audio, Canada / US)
Meanings Lacking elegance, precision, or care
Quick and neat in action; skillful
Alvarez then got on the scoresheet after the hosts carved open the Huddersfield defence with some intricate passing before the Argentina forward's deft finish rolled into the net.
—2024 January 7, Gary Rose, "Manchester City 5-0 Huddersfield Town", in BBC Sport
furtive
adjective (comparable)
Expected Actual
Pronunciation (IPA, Canada / US)
/ˈfɚtɪv/
Pronunciation (audio, Canada / US)
Meanings Flirtatious
Done with evasive or guilty secrecy
Acquired by theft, or taken stealthily
Sly, stealthy
Inclined to steal; pilfering, thieving
I noticed the same singular, and as it were, furtive glance over the shoulder that had attracted my attention in the Cassino.
—1824, Geoffrey Crayon [pseudonym; Washington Irving], "The Adventure of the Mysterious Stranger", in Tales of a Traveller, part 1 (Strange Stories), page 95
gestalt
noun (uncountable)
Expected Actual
Pronunciation (IPA, Canada / US) /dʒɛsˈtɑlt/ /ɡəˈʃtolt/
Meanings (uncountable) A mineral salt found in limestone deposits
(countable) A collection of physical, biological, psychological or symbolic elements that creates a whole, unified concept or pattern which is other than the sum of its parts due to the relationships between the parts (of a character, personality, entity, or being)
histrionic
adjective (comparable)
Expected Actual
Pronunciation (IPA, Canada / US)
/hɪstɹijˈɑnɪk/
Meanings So great as to be (preemptively) historically significant
Of or relating to actors or acting
Excessively dramatic or emotional, especially with the intention to draw attention
This lens (known as a carello ottico in Italian and a travelling optique in French) is used sparingly but effectively in General Della Rovere during the important bombardment scene inside the prison, which introduces [Vittorio] De Sica's most histrionic speech.
—2009, Peter Bondanella, "Neorealism’s Legacy to a New Generation, and the Italian Political Film", in A History of Italian Cinema, part 3 (The Golden Age of Italian Cinema), pages 219–220
implacable
adjective (comparable)
Expected Actual
Pronunciation (IPA, Canada / US) /ɪmˈplejsəbl/ /ɪmˈplækəbl/
Pronunciation (audio, Canada / US)
Meanings Not able to be placed
Not able to be placated or appeased
Impossible to prevent or stop; inexorable, unrelenting, unstoppable
Adamant; immovable
The battleships Washington and South Dakota pushed through the sea with an implacable ease.
—2011, James D. Hornfischer, "The Giants Ride", in Neptune’s Inferno: The U.S. Navy at Guadalcanal, trade paperback edition, 2012, page 345
intransigence
noun (uncountable)
Expected Actual
Pronunciation (IPA, Canada / US) /ɪnˈtʃɹæn.zɪ.dʒəns/ /ɪnˈtʃɹæn.sɪ.dʒəns/
Meanings The opposite of transience; the quality of being permanent and fixed
Unwillingness to change one's views or to agree
Meanwhile, we have encouraged and supported efforts to reach a political settlement in Afghanistan which would lead to a withdrawal of Soviet forces from that country and meet the interests of all concerned. It is Soviet intransigence that has kept those efforts from bearing fruit.
—1981 January 16, Jimmy Carter, State of the Union Address
malevolent
adjective (comparable)
Expected Actual
Pronunciation (IPA, Canada / US) /mæləˈvowlənt/ /məˈlɛvələnt/
Pronunciation (audio, Canada / US)
Meanings Benevolent
Having or displaying ill will; wishing harm on others
Having an evil or harmful influence
Vela, Javier Hernández and Lozano switched positions with a thrillingly malevolent sense of purpose.
—2018 June 17, Barney Ronay, "Mexico’s Hirving Lozano stuns world champions Germany for brilliant win", The Guardian
motley
adjective (comparable)
Expected Actual
Pronunciation (IPA, Canada / US)
/ˈmɑtlij/
Meanings Troublemaking; having little regard for others
Comprising greatly varied elements, to the point of incongruity.
Having many colours; variegated.
Even such a boat as the Mount Vernon offered a total deck space so cramped as to leave secrecy or privacy well out of the question, even had the motley and democratic assemblage of passengers been disposed to accord either.
—1910, Emerson Hough, chapter II, in The Purchase Price: Or The Cause of Compromise
ostensibly
adverb (comparable)
Expected Actual
Pronunciation (IPA, Canada / US)
/ɑˈstɛn.sə.blij/
Pronunciation (audio, Canada / US)
Meanings Extensively and ostentatiously Seemingly, apparently, on the surface
Qwertygiy, found an instance of this misunderstanding in the wild (shown below).
palimpsest
noun (countable)
Expected Actual
Pronunciation (IPA, Canada / US)
/ˈpælɪmpsɛst/
Pronunciation (audio, Canada / US)
Meanings A sore that has broken open and become infected
A manuscript or document that has been erased or scraped clean, for reuse of the paper, parchment, vellum, or other medium on which it was written
Something bearing the traces of an earlier, erased form
A text with several layers of meaning, especially pertaining to different points in time
palisade
noun (countable)
Expected Actual
Pronunciation (IPA, Canada / US)
/ˌpælɪˈsejd/
Pronunciation (audio, Canada / US)
Meanings A garden surrounding a palace or other large and beautiful building
A long, strong stake, one end of which is set firmly in the ground, and the other sharpened
phalanx
noun (countable)
Expected Actual
Pronunciation (IPA, Canada / US)
/ˈfejˌlæŋks/
Pronunciation (audio, Canada / US)
Meanings A Tolkienian palantir
A large group of people, animals or things, compact or closely massed, or tightly knit and united in common purpose
An ancient Greek and Macedonian military unit that consisted of several ranks and files (lines) of soldiers in close array with joined shields and long spears
posterity
noun (uncountable)
Expected Actual
Pronunciation (IPA, Canada / US)
/pɑˈstɛɹɪtij/
Pronunciation (audio, Canada / US)
Meanings Public perception; reputation
All the future generations, especially the descendants of a specific person
'Now, this gentleman is an old man, and that is quite enough to render him ridiculous in your eyes. You, who talk of emancipating your serfs, and "doing something for posterity," indeed! I tell you what it is, it's your Shakespeare! You stuff yourself full of Shakespeare, who has long ago outlived his time, my dear Paul; and who, if he lived now, with all his wisdom, would never make head or tail of our way of life!'
—1888, Fedor Dostoieffsky, Uncle's Dream, chapter 3
precocious
adjective (comparable)
Expected Actual
Pronunciation (IPA, Canada / US)
/pɹəˈkoʊʃɪs/
Meanings Mischievous or meddlesome, but in an endearing way
Characterized by exceptionally early development or maturity
Exhibiting advanced skills and aptitudes at an abnormally early age
Now those abominations whom you call precocious boys—your little pet monsters, doctor!—and who can wonder that the world is what it is? when it is full of them—as they will have no divine time to look back upon in their own lives, how can they believe in innocence and goodness, or be other than sons of selfishness and the Devil?
—1859, George Meredith, The Ordeal of Richard Feverel, chapter 15
prig
noun (countable)
Expected Actual
Pronunciation (IPA, Canada / US)
/pɹɪɡ/
Meanings Pig (in any of its derogatory senses referring to people)
A deliberately superior person; a person who demonstrates an exaggerated conformity or propriety, especially in an irritatingly arrogant or smug manner
profligacy
noun
Expected Actual
Pronunciation (IPA, Canada / US) /pɹoʊˈflɪɡəsij/ /ˈpɹɑflɪɡəsij/
Meanings (uncountable) Prolificness
(countable) Careless wastefulness
(uncountable) Shameless and immoral behaviour
Outsiders who scoffed at this profligacy misunderstood the masquerade. Condé's editors were the original influencers, their lives a top-to-bottom marketing campaign for the company that hired them.
—2025, Michael M. Grynbaum, The New York Times, "The Concorde-and-Caviar Era of Condé Nast, When Magazines Ruled the Earth"
provenance
noun
Expected Actual
Pronunciation (IPA, Canada / US)
/ˈpɹɑ.və.nəns/, /ˈpɹow.və.nɑns/
Meanings (uncountable) Pomp and circumstance
(countable) Place or source of origin
(countable, of a person) Background; history
Within this melee of intersections between English and Cantonese, the students, being themselves bilingually fluent, were able to navigate with perfect ease in communicative contexts where the provenance of a certain term or expression matters little.
—2015, James Lambert, Dictionaries and corpora: Innovations in reference science (Proceedings of ASIALEX 2015 Hong Kong), "Lexicography as a teaching tool: A Hong Kong case study", page 147
pulchritude
noun (uncountable)
Expected Actual
Pronunciation (IPA, Canada / US)
/ˈpəl.krəˌtuwd/
Meanings Putridity
Physical beauty
Do you know why a woman of such pulchritude is married to me? 'Cause I make a comfortable living.
—1979, Carl Reiner, The Jerk, 00:18:20
putative
adjective (comparable)
Expected Actual
Pronunciation (IPA, Canada / US)
/ˈpjuw.tə.tɪv/
Meanings Punitive
Commonly believed or deemed to be the case; generally assumed
Accepted by supposition rather than as a result of proof
Alleged; ostensible
Just as Prince Sihanouk is fronting for the Khmer Rouge today . . . so also was he their putative leader from 1970 to 1975.
—1989, William E. Colby and Jeremy J. Stone, Milwaukee Sentinel (Los Angeles Times Service), October 28, "US must support Thailand if Cambodia is to survive"
spatchcock
To partially cook by boiling
steeplechase
The act of continually attending a different church each week, searching for some magical connection that is not found in any particular church, but only in God himself.
A children's playground game in which one child holds a stick vertically above their head, and others chase them.
steppe
A region of mountainous, rocky terrain
stigmatic or stigmatist
noun (countable)
Expected Actual
Pronunciation (IPA, Canada / US)
/stɪɡˈmætɪk/; /ˈstɪɡməˌtɪst/
Meanings One who stigmatizes
One who displays stigmata, the five wounds of Christ
One who has been branded as punishment
terrace
A low, wooden fence
weevil
Weasel
jingo (noun, countable) A goofy person A member of the Insane Clown Posse
